articles.headline: China Said to Widen Its Embargo of Minerals
articles.snippet: An interruption of rare earth exports beyond Japan may signal Beijing’s willingness to flex its growing economic muscle.
articles.abstract: An interruption of rare earth exports beyond Japan may signal Beijing’s willingness to flex its growing economic muscle.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China, which has been blocking shipments of crucial minerals to Japan for the last month, has now quietly halted some shipments of those materials to the United States and Europe, three industry officials said this week.

articles.headline: Intermission, at Best, in Battle Over Foreclosures
articles.snippet: Despite Bank of America’s announcement that it will resume foreclosures, state law-enforcement officials and the White House say they will continue their inquiries.
articles.abstract: Despite Bank of America’s announcement that it will resume foreclosures, state law-enforcement officials and the White House say they will continue their inquiries.
articles.lead_paragraph: Bank of America may be trying to bring down the curtain on the foreclosure furor, but there were numerous indications Tuesday that the problems would not move off-stage so quickly.

articles.headline: Officer Failed to Warn C.I.A. Before Attack
articles.snippet: Before a Jordanian doctor bombed an Afghanistan base last December, a C.I.A. officer was told he might work for Al Qaeda, an investigation revealed.
articles.abstract: Before a Jordanian doctor bombed an Afghanistan base last December, a C.I.A. officer was told he might work for Al Qaeda, an investigation revealed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Three weeks before a Jordanian double agent set off a bomb at a remote Central Intelligence Agency base in eastern Afghanistan last December, a C.I.A. officer in Jordan received warnings that the man might be working for Al Qaeda, according to an investigation into the deadly attack.

articles.headline: Clarence Thomas’s Wife Asks Anita Hill for Apology
articles.snippet: Virginia Thomas called Ms. Hill about sexual harassment accusations she made against Justice Thomas in 1991.
articles.abstract: Virginia Thomas called Ms. Hill about sexual harassment accusations she made against Justice Thomas in 1991.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Nearly 20 years after Anita Hill accused Clarence Thomas of sexual harassment during his contentious Supreme Court confirmation hearings, Justice Thomas’s wife has called Ms. Hill, seeking an apology.

articles.headline: Taliban Elite, Aided by NATO, Join Talks for Afghan Peace
articles.snippet: Talks are underway between President Hamid Karzai’s inner circle and top Taliban commanders, who are secretly leaving Pakistan with the help of NATO troops, officials say.
articles.abstract: Talks are underway between President Hamid Karzai’s inner circle and top Taliban commanders, who are secretly leaving Pakistan with the help of NATO troops, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  Talks to end the war in Afghanistan involve extensive, face-to-face discussions with Taliban commanders from the highest levels of the group’s leadership, who are secretly leaving their sanctuaries in Pakistan with the help of NATO troops, officials here say.

articles.headline: U.S. Military Moves to Accept Gay Recruits
articles.snippet: The military began the new policy to comply with decisions by a federal judge in California.
articles.abstract: The military began the new policy to comply with decisions by a federal judge in California.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States military, for the first time, is allowing its recruiters to accept openly gay and lesbian applicants.

articles.headline: As G.O.P. Seeks Spending Cuts, Details Are Scarce
articles.snippet: Budget analysts said Republicans were glossing over the difficulty of carrying out their ideas.
articles.abstract: Budget analysts said Republicans were glossing over the difficulty of carrying out their ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In Indiana, Representative Mike Pence, the No. 3 House Republican, complains about “runaway federal spending on steroids.”

articles.headline: Fed Wants Banks to Buy Back Some Bad Mortgages
articles.snippet: Two years after the Fed bought billions of dollars in mortgage securities as part of the financial bailout, it is pressing banks to buy some of them back.
articles.abstract: Two years after the Fed bought billions of dollars in mortgage securities as part of the financial bailout, it is pressing banks to buy some of them back.
articles.lead_paragraph: To the long list of those picking fights with banks over bad mortgages, add the Federal Reserve.

articles.headline: Insurers Test New Cancer Pay Systems
articles.snippet: Insurers are urging doctors to use standard treatments instead of individualized, unproven courses of therapy.
articles.abstract: Insurers are urging doctors to use standard treatments instead of individualized, unproven courses of therapy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several large health insurers, including UnitedHealthcare and Aetna, are focusing on one of the country’s most costly diseases: cancer.

articles.headline: Proving Innovation in Medicare
articles.snippet: A proposal to rein in Medicare spending would allow coverage of treatments for three years to prove that they work better than cheaper treatments.
articles.abstract: A proposal to rein in Medicare spending would allow coverage of treatments for three years to prove that they work better than cheaper treatments.
articles.lead_paragraph: The huge budget deficits that the country faces in coming decades are, above all, because of Medicare. The program will have to cover growing numbers of baby boomers while health costs are likely to keep going up.
